item.title: Sample Page
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:
Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my website. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)
...or something like this:
The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.
As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

item.title: 10 Advanced PHP Tips To Improve Your Programming
item.dc:creator: dhawalm
item.content:encoded:
PHP programming has climbed rapidly since its humble beginnings in 1995. Since then, PHP has become the most popular programming language for Web applications. Many popular websites are powered by PHP, and an overwhelming majority of scripts and Web projects are built with the popular language. Because of PHP’s huge popularity, it has become almost impossible for Web developers not to have at least a working knowledge of PHP. This tutorial is aimed at people who are just past the beginning stages of learning PHP and are ready to roll up their sleeves and get their hands dirty with the language. Listed below are 10 excellent techniques that PHP developers should learn and use every time they program. These PHP tips will speed up proficiency and make the code much more responsive, cleaner and more optimized for performance. [huge_it_share]

1. Use an SQL Injection Cheat Sheet

SQL Injection attacks allow attackers to spoof identity, tamper with existing data, cause repudiation issues such as voiding transactions or changing balances, allow the complete disclosure of all data on the system, destroy the data or make it otherwise unavailable, and become administrators of the database server. Furruh Mavituna has a very nifty SQL injection cheat sheet that has a section on vulnerabilities with PHP and MySQL. If you can avoid the practices the cheat sheet identifies, your code will be much less prone to scripting attacks.

2. Shortcut the else

It should be noted that tips 3 and 4 both might make the code slightly less readable. The emphasis for these tips is on speed and performance. If you’d rather not sacrifice readability, then you might want to skip them. Anything that can be done to make the code simpler and smaller is usually a good practice. One such tip is to take the middleman out of else statements, so to speak. Christian Montoya has an excellent example of conserving characters with shorter else statements.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: 10 Advanced PHP Tips To Improve Your Programming

I am a Web Designer cum Web Developer from India living in Mumbai. I am working in a professional web designing company based in Mumbai. During my free time, I like to freelance as this is what i like to do and where my passion is. As a web designer, I am mainly in to interface designing of websites and online applications, and GUI development. I visualize design and develop websites in a professional way. My approach towards providing maximum client satisfaction is to offer most trendiest and international level websites.

I have worked on web based projects for a range of clients providing Web Design and Development (PHP, HTML, CSS, JS, jQuery, WordPress, Bootstrap, Angular JS, Responsive Layouts), eCommerce Solutions, Corporate Branding and Graphic Design. During my working experience I have studied design logic & perspective, and therefore have a keen understanding of wireframes, sitemaps and user experience design which I put to good use on every project I work on.

item.title: What is Bootstrap? How to use it?
item.dc:creator: dhawalm
item.content:encoded:
Bootstrap is a free and open-source front-end web framework for designing responsive or mobile friendly websites and web applications. It contains HTML and CSS templates for typography, forms, buttons, navigation and other interface components, as well as optional JavaScript extensions. Bootstrap, originally known as Twitter Blueprint was developed by Mark Otto and Jacob Thornton at Twitter as a framework to encourage consistency across internal tools. Currently Bootstrap v4.0 is under develop which will enhance more features & easy developing of Responsive website & web application. Bootstrap consist of :
  • CSS
  • Javascript
  • Fonts for icons

How to use Bootstrap?

First of all, you need to download Bootstrap from their website, its completely FREE. After downloading the required files, unzip the compressed folder & copy the files into your project folder. Once you copied the files, you have call those required files to your HTML. Follow the below steps to integrate the bootstrap files into your project:
  1. Calling CSS files to your project : 
    <link href="path-of-your-folder/bootstrap.min.css" rel="stylesheet">
  2. Attaching JS files : 
    <script src="path-of-your-folder/bootstrap.min.js" rel="stylesheet"></script>

Bootstrap Basic Template

You can use below basic HTML template to start working & using bootstrap: 
<!DOCTYPE html>
  <html lang="en">    
	<head>      
	<meta charset="utf-8">      
   <meta http-equiv="X-UA-Compatible" content="IE=edge">      
   <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1">      
   <title>What is Bootstrap? How to use it?</title>
   <link href="css/bootstrap.min.css" rel="stylesheet">           
   </head>    
<body>      
<h1>Hello, world!</h1>        
<script src="https://ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.11.3/jquery.min.js"></script>      
<script src="js/bootstrap.min.js"></script>    
</body>  
</html>

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Get to know Bootstrap | What is Bootstrap | How to use Bootstrap
Learn Bootstrap with well organized and easy way, get to know about Bootstrap? What is Bootstrap? How to use it?. Tips to use Bootstrap by MadeByDhawal

item.title: 05 Free Web Tools
item.dc:creator: dhawalm
item.content:encoded:
Who doesn't love free stuff? Here I provide 10 Free Web Tools you can use while working on web. The web tools movement is as hot as ever and there are plenty of free, high-quality options available. If I can find a free tool to do something, I'm going to try the free one first. As long as I can attain the same quality result from the free tool, there's no need to waste fund. [huge_it_share] Here are some of best free web tools available online, have a look :

01. ai2Html

ai2html is an open-source script for Adobe Illustrator that converts your Illustrator documents into HTML and CSS, from the developers at the New York Times. It looks really a helpful and useful tools for designers who work in Adobe Illustrator.

02. HTMLHint

This is a Static Code Analysis Tool for HTML, you can use it with IDE or in build system. This tool has many options available and lets you check through the warnings and errors in your HTML code.

03. Canva Infographic Maker

Canva is a one of the strong online image and infographic maker that allows you to make designs even if you do not have any design knowledge with help of their predefined templates, elements, images and much more. Canva provides many different templates for you to pick which can be posted on Social Platform’s like Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr and many more. Canva is available with FREE version as well as Paid Version

04. Google Developers

To connect your data with real time, you can use Google Developers which is the perfect way to generate infographic for your website. Google chart tools are powerful, simple to use, and free. You have a variety of charts to choose from and configure an big set of options to perfectly match the look and feel of your website.

05. Font Library

Need perfect font combination for your next project? We have a tool or website named Font Library which makes it easy for users to find great combinations of fonts. It is is an open-source project to tag, organize and make it easier to browse Google Fonts.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: 05 Free Web Tools for Web Designer & Developer | Free Web Tools
We have many free web tools available on web world for web designer and developer, so here are some best Free Web Tools by MadebyDhawal

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: 10 Web Tools for daily use making developer & designer life hazel free.

item.title: 05 New Things You Must Know About HTML5 Tags
item.dc:creator: dhawalm
item.content:encoded:
HTML5 is now becoming a tendering topic among web designers and developers as well as bloggers. So, are you interest in HTML5 also? Then you’re come to the right place. HTML5 brings a lot of new elements and features to allow developers & designer to make their projects more easily understood by search engines, display data more uniquely, and take on some of the load that has required complex JavaScript or browser plug-ins like Flash and Silverlight to handle. Here are 10 new items in HTML5 that will make it easier for you to write your Web sites.

01. A new DOCTYPE declaration

As a HTML Developer, we used to have problems remembering long and complicated HTML4 / XHTML 1.0 doctype like below? 
<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Transitional//EN"
<http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">
The new doctype by HTML5, which is simple and easy to remember, which is one of the main reason or feature using HTML5 . Here it is: 
<!DOCTYPE html>

02. No more Type attribute for script and link

This is how we developers use to define script and link tags in HTML4. 
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="style.css" />
<script type="text/javascript" src="script.js"></script>
In HTML5, the life of developer is made hazzel free by reducing some attributes from HTML5 tags, so you don’t have to specify the type value for your script and link tag. You can simply write your code as: 
<link rel="stylesheet" href="style.css" />
<script src="script.js"></script>

03. Semantic Structure - header and footer

Previously we used id & classes for HTML structure which was no semantic by nature. HTML5 has created new semantic structure for <header> and <footer>. 
<header> ..... </header> 
<footer> ... </footer>

04. Form Input Types and Attributes

HTML5 has also introduce many for form and input tags & attributes to make the form development more convenient & ease life for developers. However, new HTML5 form tags are not supported by all browsers especially the old version. Here are some form and input tags & attributes which you can try: 
<form id="myform">
Name: <input name="name" required placeholder="Your name" pattern="[A-z]{7}" />
<br/>
Email: <input type="email" name="email" required placeholder="email@inwebson.com"/>
<br/>
URL: <input type="url" name="url" placeholder="Homepage URL"/>
<br/>
Age: <input type="number" name="age" min="18" max="99" />
<br/>
Description: <textarea name="desc" placeholder="Describe yourself here..."></textarea>
<br/>
<input type="submit" value="Submit" />
</form>

05. Audio and Video Support

My favorite pick for "best new HTML5 feature" is the video and audio tag. Previously, to embed an audio or video file on web page we have to use third party plugin like Flash through <object> and <embed> tags. With HTML5, we don’t have to rely on other plugins and their problem. But for the time being, not all browsers but most recent version of browsers offer support for HTML5

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: We all know that HTML5 has introduced many new tags and elements as well as attributes and features. Some of these HTML5 are really useful for developers.

item.title: Importance of Responsive Design
item.dc:creator: dhawalm
item.content:encoded:
A responsive web design is a site that is able to adapt to the screen resolution it is being used on. The website automatically reformats to give the user a better experience that it well suited to their device, and can give your site a number of benefits as well as being in line with Google recommendations.

Increase in mobile usage

Ofcom reported that two thirds of people in the UK now own a smartphone, using it for at least two hours every day to browse the internet, scroll through social media, carry out online banking and even online shop. 33% of internet users see their smartphone as the most important device for going online, and we spend twice as long online with our smartphones than laptops or personal computers. This could have a direct impact on the way we view websites. Ofcom’s report revealed that in 2014 only 22% turned to their phone first for browsing the internet; proving a real surge in mobile use. The availability of 4G has also impacted how people use their mobile devices. Over the course of 2014, 4G subscriptions skyrocketed from 2.7 million to 23.6 million. For these reasons alone, it is important that you have a website that works well on a smartphone or other mobile device’s screen, due to the sheer amount of people who could be using your website through a smartphone or tablet. Google’s recommendations Google constantly updates its preference and the way it looks at websites, and one of the latest recommendations from the internet powerhouse is to have a responsive web design. Google now uses mobile friendliness as a ranking signal in search results. In other words, Google is rewarding sites that are fully optimised for mobile platforms. With responsive web design now deemed best practice for industries, its importance only increases in 2016. But what exactly can a responsive website bring to your business? Benefits of responsive web design With a responsive website, the content and pages are automatically flexible, fluid across all screen resolutions and various devices. In other words, no matter what device you are viewing a website on, the user will have optimal viewing experience including ease of navigation with a minimum amount of resizing and scrolling. A responsive design can improve user experience and accommodate everyone, whether they are on a desktop or a smartphone or tablet. In providing the best possible experience, people will have a positive opinion of your website, meaning they will most probably return. Through ensuring that your website is responsive, you essentially only have one website instead of two. This is much more cost effective; as opposed to having a separate mobile site to maintain, you only have your main site to look after. Likewise, SEO campaigns are much easier to maintain with only one site; if you were to have a separate mobile site, you then have two SEO campaigns. A responsive website is all round much easier to manage. With the importance of mobile-friendly websites only increasing, take a minute to ensure your web design is the best it can be!

item.title: Sample Box
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Hello world.

This is a sample box, with some sample content in it.
